[[File:Union Army brigadier general rank insignia.svg|border|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] |commands= [[6th Minnesota Volunteer Infantry Regiment|6th Minnesota Infantry]] |unit= |battles= [[American Civil War]] |awards= |laterwork= U.S. Congressman }} '''John Thomas Averill''' (March 1, 1825 – October 3, 1889) was a [[United States Army]] officer in the [[American Civil War]] who later became a U.S. congressional representative from [[Minnesota]].Eicher, John H., and Eicher, David J., Civil War High Commands, Stanford University Press, 2001, ISBN 0-8047-3641-3. ==Early life and education== Averill was born in [[Alna, Maine]], March 1, 1825. He moved with his parents to [[Montville, Maine]] in 1838 and graduated from the [[Kents Hill School|Maine Wesleyan Seminary]] at [[Readfield]] in 1846. He taught school for a short time, and subsequently engaged in lumbering for one year. Averill then moved to [[Winthrop, Maine]], and engaged in mercantile pursuits for three years. In 1852 he moved to northern [[Pennsylvania]] and again engaged in lumbering until 1857, when he settled in [[Lake City, Minnesota]]. Once there, he engaged in mercantile pursuits and the grain business; was a member of the [[Minnesota Senate]] 1858 – 1860. ==Career== On August 22, 1862, Averill was commissioned as a lieutenant colonel of the [[6th Minnesota Volunteer Infantry Regiment|6th Minnesota Infantry Regiment]]. He was promoted to Colonel on November 22, 1864, and was assigned as [[Provost Marshal|Provost Marshal General]] for the District of Minnesota. He was honorably mustered out on September 28, 1865; and was made a [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] on October 18, 1865. In 1866 he moved to [[St. Paul, Minnesota]] and engaged in the wholesale paper and stationery business. He was a member of the [[Republican National Committee]] from 1868 through 1880; elected as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to the [[42nd United States Congress|42nd]] and [[43rd United States Congress|43rd]] congresses (March 4, 1871 – March 3, 1875); He was chairman of the [[Committee on Indian Affairs]] (Forty-third Congress); was not a candidate for renomination in 1874. ==Later life and death== Averill resumed his business activities in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], where he died on October 3, 1889; interred at the [[Oakland Cemetery (Saint Paul, Minnesota)|Oakland Cemetery]]. He is the namesake of the community of [[Averill, Minnesota]].{{cite book|last=Upham|first=Warren|title=Minnesota Geographic Names: Their Origin and Historic Significance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ShcLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA115|year=1920|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society|page=115}} ==References== {{Reflist|col=30em}} == External links == {{MN-legdb|11036}} *[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=5993459 John T.
